Award.AwardTitle: Proposal for Conference/Workshop Support for CECAM workshop: Self-assembly: from fundamental Principles to Design Rules for Experiment; Lausanne, Switzerland; March 1 - 3, 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1256701 PI: Hagan, Michael ORG: Brandeis University

Title: Proposal for Conference/Workshop Support for CECAM workshop: Self-assembly: from fundamental principles to design rules for experiment

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The proposal asks for funds to support the travel and subsistence costs for seven early-career US scientists to attend a workshop to be held at the Centre Europeen de Calcul Atomique et Moleculaire (CECAM) in Lausanne, Switzerland. This workshop aims to bring together computer simulators and experimentalists whose work bears upon the fundamental rules that govern soft matter self-assembly. Participants will be united not by their study of a particular physical system, but by their focus on the forces that control assembly. The proposed speaker list is highly multidisciplinary, and includes theoretical physicists, virologists, synthetic biologists, and materials scientists. Despite their common interests, researchers who study biological assemblages and those who study crystallization rarely overlap. The format of a CECAM workshop provides an ideal environment to bring members of these fields together to benefit from commonalities in subject and complementary techniques used in each of these fields.

BROADER IMPACTS: It is anticipated that the workshop will have a much broader impact than that realized from a typical conference. Speakers and attendees from a wide range of disciplines, geographical locations, and career stages will engage in intensive small-group discussions. Thus, participants with different areas of expertise, experience levels, genders, and ethnic backgrounds will interact closely. NSF funding support will be given to both emerging scientists (students, postdocs, and junior faculty) and under-represented groups in order to increase their participation. Such support will help fulfill the urgent, national need to train the future scientific community in the areas of nanotechnology and biological research. Furthermore, by encouraging US scientists to attend through NSF support, the workshop will serve to increase the engagement of the US with the European soft matter community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided travel assistance to US scientists attending a Centre Européen de Calcul Atomique et Moléculaire (CECAM) workshop in Lausanne, Switzerland. The workshop (described at http://www.cecam.org/workshop-0-694.html) brought together computer simulators and experimentalists whose work bears upon the fundamental rules that govern self-assembly, which is a process in which simple units spontaneously form larger, more complex structures. Understanding self-assembly is one of the grand challenges in statistical physics, and self-assembly plays essential roles in biological systems and material science applications. The workshop brought together speakers from a range of disciplines, including theoretical physics, virology, and materials science. Our understanding of several basic principles of self-assembly has been advanced by recent computer simulations; the workshop placed these new ideas side-by-side with recent work in which control of assembly was demonstrated in real systems, in order for experimentalists and simulators to learn from each other. Questions that the workshop focused on included how general concepts like ‘reversibility’ and other lessons learned from simple models can be translated into improvements in experimental design? And can we extract general principles from the successful control of specific experiments? Potential long-term applications from the work discussed at this workshop include new antiviral drugs, new designs of drug delivery vehicles, and novel advanced materials that can dynamically reconfigure in response to external perturbations. An important feature of the workshop was that it provided numerous opportunities for junior researchers (graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and new assistant professors) to interact with established researchers, providing essential guidance and networking opportunities for career development and scientific advancement.  By assisting the travel of US scientists to this workshop, this grant helped to increase the engagement of the US with the strong biophysical and soft condensed matter physics communities in Europe and other parts of the world.
